title: 109_hr5928
content:
The "21st Century High-Performing Public School Facilities Act of 2006" includes provisions for grants, low-interest loans, and general provisions related to the construction, modernization, or repair of school facilities. The Act outlines criteria for awarding grants, allowable uses of funds, and the establishment of a revolving fund for low-interest loans. Title II of the "21st Century High-Performing Public School Facilities Act of 2006" focuses on Educational Technology Funding, including provisions for impermissible uses of funds, maintenance of effort, fair wages, reporting, and authorization of appropriations. The Congress acknowledges the urgent need for extensive repair and modernization of the Nation's public school buildings, as highlighted by the American Society of Civil Engineers' 2005 report card giving schools a D grade. Hundreds of billions of dollars are required to bring schools up to modern standards in terms of structure, education, and health. Improving public school facilities is crucial for student academic performance and teacher retention. The Federal government needs to do more to help states and school districts upgrade their facilities. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include "Bureau-funded school," "charter school," "local educational agency," and "outlying area." The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and the term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. TITLE I--21ST CENTURY HIGH-PERFORMING PUBLIC SCHOOL FACILITIES

Subtitle A--Grants for Construction, Modernization, or Repair of School Facilities

SEC. 101. GRANTS.

The Secretary of Education will provide grants to local educational agencies in each State for constructing, modernizing, or repairing safe, healthy, high-performing, and technologically up-to-date public educational facilities.

SEC. 102. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary reserves 1 percent of the funds for assistance to outlying areas and Bureau-funded schools. The remaining funds are allocated for grants to local educational agencies in each State based on the amount received under part A of title I. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to local educational agencies in each State based on the amount received under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Within each State, a portion of the funds is reserved for agencies receiving assistance under section 1124A of the Act. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to local educational agencies in each State based on the amount received under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The funds are distributed relative to the total amount received by all local educational agencies in the State for the previous fiscal year. SEC. 103. PRIORITY; CRITERIA FOR AWARDING GRANTS. Priority in awarding grants under this subtitle is given to local educational agencies with higher numbers or percentages of children in need, as well as those demonstrating a need for school construction, modernization, or repair. Additionally, the Secretary considers the fiscal capacity of the agency to meet these needs. The local educational agency's ability to fund construction projects for public school facilities, including access to funding for charter schools, maintenance of assisted facilities, and plans to obtain private funding. The local educational agency's plan to secure private business contributions for funding, as required by the Internal Revenue Code, without being penalized for inability to obtain such contributions despite good faith efforts. SEC. 104. The Secretary requires local educational agencies to provide matching funds based on poverty levels. In-kind contributions are allowed to meet this requirement. SEC. 105 outlines allowable uses of funds. A grant under this subtitle can be used by a local educational agency for repairing and modernizing public school facilities to ensure health and safety, including roofs, electrical wiring, plumbing, HVAC systems, and fire codes compliance. It can also be used for modifications to make facilities accessible under the Americans with Disabilities Act and Rehabilitation Act. The grant under this subtitle can be used for various purposes including asbestos abatement, lead-based paint hazard reduction, upgrading educational technology, making school facilities energy-efficient, and constructing new school facilities with modern amenities. The grant under this subtitle can be used for various purposes, including upgrading educational technology and infrastructure where economically feasible. The grant under this subtitle can be used for upgrading educational technology and infrastructure where economically feasible. SEC. 106. APPLICATION FOR GRANT. The local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under this subtitle. The application should include consultation with parents and teachers, details on school facilities, capacity for enrollments, and availability of infrastructure for educational technology. The application for a grant under this subtitle must include a description of improvements, a cost estimate, identification of available resources, and other required information. Subtitle B outlines the provision of low-interest loans for the construction, modernization, or repair of school facilities. The Secretary provides low-interest loans to local educational agencies for safe, healthy, and technologically up-to-date school facilities. Priority is given to certain agencies, and criteria are considered for loan approval. Funds can be used for specified activities, and loan amounts and conditions are regulated by the Secretary. The Secretary ensures that loans for school facilities do not exceed construction costs and are repaid within 30 years. Established in the Treasury is a revolving fund called the School Construction, Modernization, and Repair Revolving Fund, consisting of amounts from a loan program and appropriations. The fund is available to the Secretary without fiscal year limitation to carry out the provisions of this subtitle. Subtitle C--General Provisions

SEC. 121. IMPERMISSIBLE USES OF FUNDS: Funds under this title cannot be used for maintenance costs or stadiums primarily used for events with admission fees.

SEC. 122. SUPPLEMENT, NOT SUPPLANT: Local educational agencies must use Federal funds to supplement, not replace, funds for construction, modernization, and repair of educational facilities.

SEC. 123. MAINTENANCE OF EFFORT. SEC. 123. MAINTENANCE OF EFFORT. A local educational agency must maintain a certain level of fiscal effort per student or aggregate expenditures to be eligible for grants or loans. SEC. 124. SPECIAL RULE. Agencies must ensure fair competition for construction contracts, including small, minority, and women-owned businesses. SEC. 125. APPLICATION OF GEPA. SEC. 125. APPLICATION OF GEPA. The grant and loan programs are subject to the General Education Provisions Act and reporting requirements. SEC. 126. REPORTING. Local educational agencies must submit reports on the use of grant or loan funds by December 31 each fiscal year. The Secretary must also submit reports to relevant committees on grants and loans made under this title, detailing construction, modernization, repair projects, and the number of students impacted. SEC. 127. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 127. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $6.4 billion authorized for fiscal year 2007 and necessary sums for 2008-2011 for subtitles A, B, and C. 85% reserved for subtitle A and up to 15% for subtitle B. SEC. 201. EDUCATIONAL TECHNOLOGY FUNDING. $1 billion authorized for fiscal year 2007 for subparts 1 and 2 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
